abstracts.cdata!:
The audit rates the outcome of the
            project as satisfactory, sustainability as highly likely,
            and its institutional development impact as substantial,
            while both the Bank, and Borrower performances are
            satisfactory. Valuable lessons are drawn form the project.
            The need for a focused project design is addressed, in light
            of the complexity of this project, which was conducive to
            many implementation delays. Furthermore, it is emphasized,
            that a Performance Management Framework, be included in
            future project design, to provide an early, and continuous
            assessment, of not only the input assessment of the project,
            but on the outcomes of education quality improvements, and,
            on the relevance of vocational training as well. Above all,
            it should include evaluations to measure the effect of
            investments in capacity building, improved training
            facilities, and better-trained staff, in addition to the
            cost effectiveness of public sector training. Implementation
            procedures should be clearly defined, so as to be fully
            understood and accepted by local authorities, early on at
            project preparation; likewise, project management staff
            should be fully trained at the early stages, to properly
            apply administrative, and financial management procedures,
            and thus avoid the capacity building failure experimented in
            those areas, resulting from weak supervision missions.

18156704.admreg: East Asia and Pacific,East Asia and Pacific
18156704.theme: Rural services and infrastructure,Education for all,Gender,Improving labor markets
18156704.trustfund:
TF020760-AUSTRALIAN CONSULTANTS TRUST
            FUND - 0,TF022212-CANADIAN GENERAL CTF II-PHILIPPINES
18156704.majtheme: Rural development,Human development,Social dev/gender/inclusion,Social protection and risk management

abstracts.cdata!:
The project will: (a) strengthen
            institutional capabilities in policy formation, planning,
            and management of nonformal vocational training and
            employment services; (b) improve training standards by
            strengthening training support services and developing
            mechanisms to increase cost sharing and cost recovery for
            training; (c) improve facilities and programs for nonformal
            vocational education by (i) upgrading Regional and
            Provincial Manpower Training Centers and the National Skills
            Training Center, (ii) providing incentives to the private
            sector to increase its provision of on-the-job training,
            (iii) improving the apprenticeship program, and (iv)
            supporting training in rural areas for women as well as
            unemployed and out of school youth; finally (d) conduct two
            studies under the auspices of the Council of the National
            Manpower and Youth Council to: (i) define a strategy and
            investment plan for the rationalization and improvement of
            formal technical and vocational education and training, and
            (ii) determine the feasibility of establishing sector
            specific and advanced technology training centers.
